commit_message:
Network IP Availability Extension API

Add a new network IP availability API Extension for operators to predict
and react when networks are reaching IP capacity.

ip availability api extension rfe

APIImpact
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ifd42982aea5bbfc095e30bd2a221ec472d55519a
Implements: blueprint network-ip-usage-api
Closes-Bug: 1457986
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/03/180803/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================== Network IP Usage Extension ========================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/network-ip-usage-api **Wouldn't it be nice if we knew when a network or one of its subnets were nearly exhausted?** This blueprint describes a Neutron API extension that adds the ability for an administrator (or monitor) to call an API that returns a breakdown of usage details for each public network. A monitor could then alert cloud operators when thresholds have been crossed so they know to add more capacity. The goal of this blueprint is to provide a simple API extension that will get this IP usage information. Problem Description =================== The basic problem this blueprint is trying to solve: **Need an API to determine network IP usage.** A detailed description of the problem: Cloud administrators need a way to know when a network's IP range is approaching capacity. * Use Case #1: Admin invokes API extension to get detailed information about network IP usage. From that data, admin can act on networks that are nearly full. * Use Case #2: Monitor periodically calls API extention to get ip usage information. Outside the scope of this blueprint: Monitor examines results to see if any network has exceed a threshold and notifies cloud administrators to add capacity. Proposed Change =============== We propose adding an read-only (GET) API extension that retrieves usage information from existing data structures currently in OpenStack. To create this API, we plan on creating a services extension that an admin can configure and add to their deployment. This could also be implemented (if community so desires) permanently into the API (non-extension) API Extension Proposal **GET /v2.0/network-ip-usages** Example curl :: curl -i -k -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H "X-Auth-Token: SOME_AUTH_TOKEN" https://neutron-api-server.test.com:9696/v2.0/network-ip-usages Example Request :: Request to url: v2.0/network-ip-usages headers: {'content-type': 'application/json', 'X-Auth-Token': 'SOME_AUTH_TOKEN'} Example Response :: { "network_ip_usages": [ { "id": "2d5fe344-4e98-4ccc-8c91-b8064d17c64c", "name": "g1_dev_public", "subnet_ip_usages": [ { "subnet_id": "c62782ae-20bc-4396-aebe-ae700fa61688", "total_ips": 120, "used_ips": 27 }, { "subnet_id": "da58837c-cc13-4b55-bfad-3f8c9af32998", "total_ips": 248, "used_ips": 4 } ], "total_ips": 368, "used_ips": 31 }, { "id": "55e1b92a-a2a3-4d64-a2d8-4b0bee46f3bf", "name": "g1_dev_public2", "subnet_ip_usages": [ { "subnet_id": "6ff457a9-d7a7-4746-96cf-73da53049d3a", "total_ips": 120, "used_ips": 7 } ], "total_ips": 120, "used_ips": 7 } ] } **GET /v2.0/network-ip-usages/{network-id}** Example curl :: curl -i -k -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H "X-Auth-Token: SOME_AUTH_TOKEN" https://neutron-api-server.test.com:9696/v2.0/network-ip-usages/2d5fe344-4e98-4ccc-8c91-b8064d17c64c Example Request :: Request to url: /v2.0/network-ip-usages/2d5fe344-4e98-4ccc-8c91-b8064d17c64c headers: {'content-type': 'application/json', 'X-Auth-Token': 'SOME_AUTH_TOKEN'} Example response :: { "network_ip_usage": { "id": "2d5fe344-4e98-4ccc-8c91-b8064d17c64c", "name": "g1_dev_public", "subnet_ip_usages": [ { "subnet_id": "c62782ae-20bc-4396-aebe-ae700fa61688", "total_ips": 120, "used_ips": 27 }, { "subnet_id": "da58837c-cc13-4b55-bfad-3f8c9af32998", "total_ips": 248, "used_ips": 4 } ], "total_ips": 368, "used_ips": 31 } } Data Model Impact ----------------- None This information currently exists as part of the data OpenStack already owns. Some data that will be read from DB: Network, Subnet, IPAllocation The change should NOT need: new data objects, schema changes, or data migrations. REST API Impact --------------- All of the following resources are RO (GET) and are generated from querying neutron for data that already exists. This elminatates validation that would normally be introduced by other methods (POST, PUT, etc) When requesting by network_id (/v2.0/network-ip-usages/{network-id}), the network id would need to be validated. .. csv-table:: Network IP Usage :header: Attribute Name,Type,Access,Default Value,Validation Conversion,Description network_ip_usages,list,"RO, admin",generated,N/A,subnet usage list id,string (UUID),RO,"net id",N/A,network id name,string,RO,"net name",N/A,network human-readable name "total_ips",int,RO,generated,N/A,total ip count in network (note 1) "used_ips",int,RO,generated,N/A,used ip count in network (note 2) subnet_ip_usages,list,RO,generated,N/A,subnet usage counts subnet_id,string (UUID),RO,"subnet id",N/A,subnet id total_ips,int,RO,generated,N/A,total ip count in subnet cidr used_ips,int,RO,generated,N/A,used ip count in subnet Table Notes: * Note 1: total_ips for network is calculated as convenience by summing total_ips from the subnets. Each subnet's total_ips are calculated based on its range of IPs * Note 2: used_ips for network is calculated as a convenience by summing used_ips from the subnets. Gathered by aggregate query. * Specification for the method * See above Proposed Change section above for details regarding * GET /v2.0/network-ip-usages * GET /v2.0/network-ip-usages/{network_id} * Method type: GET * Normal http response code(s): 200 * Expected error http response code(s) * 400 if user provided a bad network_id * 404 if user provided a network_id that does not exist * Parameters which can be passed via the url: None * JSON schema definition for the body data if allowed * JSON schema definition for the response data if any * API Samples can be found in the Proposed Change section above * Policy Changes: Anticipating the policy for /v2.0/network-ip-usages to be admin initially and cloud administrators can open up to broader audience as they see fit via policy.json. Security Impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? **No** * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? **No** * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? **No** * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? **No** * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. **No** * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. **No, but not fully researched** Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- * Does this change have an impact on python-neutronclient? What does the user interface there look like? Yes. python-neutronclient will need to provide a means of calling this new api. Performance Impact ------------------ The 'intended' use is to provide a periodic check for an operator admin to determine remaining network capacity. With that in mind, we do not anticipate lots of load due to many API calls. Other Considerations: * This only touches the API and DB to fetch results (no external systems or agents need communication) * We anticipate 1 DB query to fetch networks and 1 DB query per subnet (may have opportunities to optimize). Code parses through the subnets IP allocations and builds the response. * We expect queries generate their counts based on indexed fields (network_id, subnet_id). This makes the aggregate queries very fast and prevents any table scans. * There shall be NO locking of records. IPv6 Impact ----------- Describe if this change will have an effect on IPv6 in Neutron. You should also document here how your change will work with the existing IPv6 infrastructure in Neutron. * Does this change work with IPv6? I believe so, but need to verify netaddr library's support of IPv6 for all supported Python versions. As of this writing, netaddr claims IPv6 support. * Does this change require Neutron changes to facilitate working with IPv6? No, but need to verify * Describe how this change will work when deployed with IPv6 tenant networks. No known impact if netaddr works as expected Other Deployer Impact --------------------- To use this new feature, deployers will need to add the extension to their list of extensions in configuration. This may be something that OpenStack could consider being part of the default extension drivers. Affects on deployment: * What config options are being added? Should they be more generic than proposed (for example a flag that other hypervisor drivers might want to implement as well)? Are the default values ones which will work well in real deployments? Configuration item: **service_plugins**. The new service plugin to add: neutron.services.network_ip_usage.plugin.IpUsagePlugin * Is this a change that takes immediate effect after its merged, or is it something that has to be explicitly enabled? **NO** Only affects deployments if admins add the extension for it. * If this change is a new binary, how would it be deployed? **N/A** * Please state anything that those doing continuous deployment, or those upgrading from the previous release, need to be aware of. Also describe any plans to deprecate configuration values or features. For example, if we change the directory name that instances are stored in, how do we handle instance directories created before the change landed? Do we move them? Do we have a special case in the code? Do we assume that the operator will recreate all the instances in their cloud? **N/A** * Does this require downtime or manual intervention to apply when upgrading? **Requires config be applied and Neutron API server restarted (naturally on every neutron server if load balanced)** Developer Impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack, such as: * If the blueprint proposes a change to the API, discussion of how other plugins would implement the feature is required. * Proposed IPAM support If neutron were to configure a non-internal IP Pool driver such as an IPAM driver, then that driver would need to be able to provide the total and used ip counts for each defined subnet. Community Impact ---------------- Describe how this change fits in with the direction the Neutron community is going. * Has the change been discussed on mailing lists, at the weekly Neutron meeting, or at a Design Summit? * Yes. Was discussed between operators at the Mid-cycle Ops meeting in Philadelphia (https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/PHL-ops-meetup). GoDaddy attendees mentioned an internal extension deployed that returns ip usage data. Other attendees queried about where this might be deployed. This resulted in publishing the following branch based on stable/juno: https://github.com/godaddy/openstack-neutron/tree/network-ip-usage * Does the change fit with the direction of the Neutron community? * Yes Alternatives ------------ What other ways could we do this thing? Why aren't we using those? This doesn't have to be a full literature review, but it should demonstrate that thought has been put into why the proposed solution is an appropriate one. I suppose an admin could: * write their own script to iterate subnets, * take the differences between the begin and end ips for the ranges, * query Neutron for a list of all IPs for each subnet and count them, * join all this data into something that allows them to know ip usage Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: David Bingham (wwriverrat) Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- * Review Proof of concept in the network-ip-usage branch here: https://github.com/godaddy/openstack-neutron/tree/network-ip-usage. As of this writing, this branch was forked from stable/juno. * Get feedback on how to go from juno/stable to master. * Refactor/fix per feedback to a master version of remote repo * Provide more thorough testing * Ensure tests work on all supported python versions * Explicitly test IPV6 (netaddr for py26 through py3) * Determine best way to test in devstack and ensure it works * Pull Request code from remote to Neutron network-ip-usage branch * Go through typical review process to get items merged into master Dependencies ============ * None Testing ======= Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc). Tempest Tests ------------- This API extension would need tempest test to exercise both endpoints. Some considerations: This this test *might* piggy-back on other tests who setup a network and consume IPs. At a time when the test has these configured, we could call both APIs and assert what should be known: total_ips and used_ips. Functional Tests ---------------- Please document any functional tests which this change will require. New features will require functional tests before being allowed to be merged. Code refactors may require functional tests. API Tests --------- Add changes to API tests in this section. This is required if the change is adding, removing, or changing any API related code in Neutron. * Add API extension tests (positive/negative) for: * /v2.0/network-ip-usages * Does it handle empty networks? * Does it handle empty sub-nets? * Does it adhere to policy.json rules? * Does it accurately reflect counts for used and total IPs? * When IPs are acquired/released, do subsequent calls reflect these changes? * /v2.0/network-ip-usage/{network_id} * (same questions as previous endpoint) * Does it gracefully handle invalid/missing/mismatched network_id? Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ A new section will need to be created to describe how to configure and what to expect from its results. Developer Documentation ----------------------- Developer API will need to be documented here: http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-networking-v2-ext.html * Endpoint: /v2.0/network-ip-usages * Endpoint: /v2.0/network-ip-usage/{network_id} References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Proof of concept code diff: https://github.com/godaddy/openstack-neutron/compare/stable/juno...godaddy:network-ip-usage * Remote description of Extension (similar to above): https://github.com/godaddy/openstack-neutron/tree/network-ip-usage/neutron/services/network_ip_usage * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. link any vendor documentation) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to

added_lines: .. Copyright 2013 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. All Rights Reserved. Author: Betsy Luzader <betsy.luzader@rackspace.com> Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. Reverse ======= Overview ------------------- Currently the /reverse endpoint is used to tie reverse dns records to ips. FloatingIPs =========== In order to use the FloatingIPs functionality you will need to have a FloatingIP associated to your project in Neutron. Set PTR for a FloatingIP ------------------------ .. http:patch:: /reverse/floatingips/(string:region):(uuid:floatingip_id) Set a PTR record for the given FloatingIP. The domain if it does not exist will be provisioned automatically. **Example request**: .. sourcecode:: http POST /reverse/floatingips/RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4bd HTTP/1.1 Host: example.com Accept: application/json Content-Type: application/json { "ptrdname" : "smtp.example.com.", "description" : "This is a floating ip for 10.0.0.1", "ttl": 600 } **Example response**: .. sourcecode:: http HTTP/1.1 202 Created Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8 Location: http://example.com:9001/v2/reverse/floatingips/RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4bd { "ptrdname": "smtp.example.com.", "ttl": 600, "description":"This is a floating ip for 172.24.4.3", "address": "172.24.4.3", "action": "CREATE", "status": "PENDING", "links":{ "self":"http://example.com:9001/v2/reverse/floatingips/RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4bd" }, "pattern":"smtp.example.com.", "created_at":"2014-03-11T21:54:57.000000", "updated_at":null, "id":"RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4bd", } :form created_at: timestamp :form updated_at: timestamp :form ptrdname: Hostname :form ttl: Time to live :form address: The FloatingIP address :form id: A combination of the Region and FloatingIP ID :form description: UTF-8 text field :form links: links to traverse the list :form action: Provisioning Action :form status: Provisioning Status :statuscode 202: Created :statuscode 401: Access Denied :statuscode 400: Invalid Object :statuscode 404: FloatingIP / PTR Not found Get a FloatingIP ---------------- .. http:get:: /reverse/floatingips/(string:region):(uuid:floatingip_id) Show's a particular FloatingIP PTR **Example request**: .. sourcecode:: http GET /reverse/floatingips/RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4bd HTTP/1.1 Host: example.com Accept: application/json **Example response**: .. sourcecode:: http HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8 { "ptrdname": "smtp.example.com.", "ttl": 600, "description":"This is a floating ip for 172.24.4.3", "address": "172.24.4.3", "action": "NONE", "status": "ACTIVE", "links":{ "self":"http://example.com:9001/v2/reverse/floatingips/RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4bd" }, "pattern":"smtp.example.com.", "created_at":"2014-03-11T21:54:57.000000", "updated_at":null, "id":"RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4bd", } :form created_at: timestamp :form updated_at: timestamp :form ptrdname: Hostname :form ttl: Time to live :form address: The FloatingIP address :form id: A combination of the Region and FloatingIP ID :form description: UTF-8 text field :form links: links to traverse the list :form action: Provisioning Action :form status: Provisioning Status :statuscode 200: OK :statuscode 404: FloatingIP or PTR not found not found List FloatingIPs ---------------- .. http:get:: /reverse/floatingips/ Lists all FloatingIPs **Example request**: .. sourcecode:: http GET /reverse/floatingips/ HTTP/1.1 Host: example.com Accept: application/json **Example response**: .. sourcecode:: http HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8 { "floatingips":[ { "ttl": 600, "ptrdname": "smtp.example.com.", "description":"This is a floating ip for 172.24.4.3", "address": "172.24.4.3", "action": "NONE", "status": "ACTIVE", "links":{ "self":"http://example.com:9001/v2/reverse/floatingips/RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4bd" }, "pattern":"smtp.example.com.", "created_at":"2014-03-11T21:54:57.000000", "updated_at":null, "id":"RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4bd", }, { "ptrdname": "www.example.com.", "ttl": 600, "description":"This is a floating ip for 172.24.4.4", "address": "172.24.4.4", "action": "NONE", "status": "ACTIVE", "links":{ "self":"http://example.com:9001/v2/reverse/floatingips/RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4be" }, "pattern":"smtp.example.com.", "created_at":"2014-03-11T21:54:57.000000", "updated_at":null, "id":"RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4be", } ], "links":{ "self":"http://127.0.0.1:9001/v2/tlds" } } :form created_at: timestamp :form updated_at: timestamp :form name: tld name :form id: uuid :form description: UTF-8 text field :form links: links to traverse the list :statuscode 200: OK :statuscode 401: Access Denied Unset PTR for a FloatingIP -------------------------- .. http:patch:: /reverse/floatingips/(string:region):(uuid:floatingip_id) Unset a PTR record for the given FloatingIP. **Example request**: .. sourcecode:: http PATCH /reverse/floatingips/RegionOne:c47229fb-0831-4b55-a5b5-380d361be4bd HTTP/1.1 Host: example.com Accept: application/json Content-Type: application/json { "ptrdname" : null, } :statuscode 202: Pending :statuscode 401: Access Denied :statuscode 400: Invalid Object :statuscode 404: FloatingIP / PTR Not found

New Liberty work starts after # all the placeholders. # # See https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/backportable-db-migrations # http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-March/006827.html from migrate.changeset.constraint import ForeignKeyConstraint from sqlalchemy.schema import MetaData, Table # This migration adds back the FKs removed in migration 80, as sqlalchemy # migrate seems to need to wait to add FKs to renamed tables. meta = MetaData() def upgrade(migrate_engine): domains_table = Table('domains', meta, autoload=True) recordsets_table = Table('recordsets', meta, autoload=True) records_table = Table('records', meta, autoload=True) fks = [] fks.append(ForeignKeyConstraint([recordsets_table.c.zone_id], [domains_table.c.id], ondelete='CASCADE')) fks.append(ForeignKeyConstraint([records_table.c.zone_id], [domains_table.c.id], ondelete='CASCADE')) for fk in fks: fk.create()

commit_message:
Remove DictCompat from BandwidthUsage

This changes over all occurrences of dictionary syntax on the
BandwidthUsage object over to use object syntax.

Change-Id: I8f344b365fccad11648282fc1cc08bb594772f85
Partially-Implements: bp rm-object-dict-compat

commit_message:
Set affinity to 1 for OpenStack-CI gate checks

This change sets the affinity for the RabbitMQ, Galera, Repo, Keystone and
Horizon containers to 1 when running on OpenStack-CI. The intention here is
to reduce the number of failures we see within the gate due to resource
starvation.

This is a temporary patch to allow other commits which reduce resource usage
to merge. This commit will be reverted once that is done.

Closes-Bug: #1498009
Change-Id: If159c75428f07e7f92c6c1807a054feca6292ad5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/87/264887/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Reduce container affinities temporarily to overcome gate check failures # with the new OpenStack-CI Cloud Providers. # TODO(odyssey4me): Revert this once the following patches have merged as # they reduce resource usage: # - https://review.openstack.org/264762 (AIO worker setting changes) # - https://review.openstack.org/264774 (Tunable Ceilometer workers) # - https://review.openstack.org/264778 (Tunable Heat workers) # - https://review.openstack.org/264780 (Tunable Horizon workers) for container_type in rabbit_mq repo galera horizon keystone; do export "NUM_${container_type}_CONTAINER=1" done

commit_message:
Optimise the workers used for all services for the AIO

The current default number of worker threads for the AIO consumes too many
resources, resulting in gate check failures.

This patch implements a set of sane defaults for the AIO, reducing the
number of workers for most services to 2.

The following differences from the Master patch are noted:
 - neutron_rpc_workers must be 0 for Kilo

Implements: blueprint gate-split
Change-Id: I553c6aa8711fa85434547585d3a56cca47539fa0
(cherry picked from commit 8e52fbb2f2c99d6b55f7dc10a3812276ce581301)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/62/264762/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Limit the number of processes used by Keystone # The defaults cause tempest failures in OpenStack CI due to resource constraints echo "keystone_wsgi_processes: 4" | tee -a /etc/openstack_deploy/user_variables.yml
